job_title: Health front associate  in Sarasota, FL

cons: - Micromanagement makes for a very unsafe work environment, speaking your mind is dismissed and not accommodated. - Management is out of control, constantly watching you throughout the day and critiquing. Lacking respect for individuals and unable to handle situations that require urgent attention for employees. - Workplace culture is miserable, negative leader perpetuating a cycle of constant criticisms instead of positivity. - Favoritism in this department is prevalent, hard work goes unacknowledged in favor of gossip in the workplace. - Management consistently creates scheduling errors that go unchanged, and throws the responsibility on the employee rather than taking action and correcting it. - Supervisor is more concerned about the presentation of the department than team morale.

But in reality, it was a pandemic and where there is fear, sometimes the best decisions are not made.

review_title: Not the worst hospital in the area but not great
pros: Worked at SMH for 5+ years in various roles. Friendly staff who are usually willing to help, resources that make your job easier such as an IV team and wound care team, decent nurse-patient ratios (usually 1:5 or 1:6 max), great benefits.
cons: Greedy CEO who wastes money on flashy things (like a fancy pizza oven for the new Venice location) instead of paying staff appropriately. Management makes no attempts to retain staff and instead shames them for leaving for better opportunities. They cut travel nurses but refused to pay more to retain staff, leaving current staff short. Management not willing to work with nurses when time off is needed (even in the case of illness/family emergency). Staff forced to return to work with COVID after only 5 days off. Inappropriate PPE even for COVID patients (SMH stopped fit testing years ago because they didn't want to spend the money on various masks to fit the nurses so they utilize CAPRs most of the time. But then upper management told staff not to use the size small face shields because they were more expensive and staff were told to wear the bigger sizes regardless of if they fit properly). Nurses told to deal with it when given patients inappropriate for their unit because getting patients out of the ER is their priority regardless of patient safety. ER nurses do not call report and send the patients to the units without warning (no fault of the ER nurses, this has been the culture there for years).

review_title: Hands down the best hospital in the area.
pros: I was challenged to further my education, something I would not have done had I not worked for SMH.
cons: Every hospital has its challenges. My only constructive criticism is about tuition reimbursement. For undergraduate degrees, the max amount is $2500/year. The hospital only reimburses for in-state rates at $70/ credit hour if I recall correctly. Since I attended a private college, I wasn't able to access $2500. 8 credits per semester per 3 semesters in a year allowed me to receive $1680 of that $2500 had I requested reimbursement. I worked for am employer in 1996 who allowed $2500 per year, so SMH doesn't provide a competitive amount of tuition reimbursement benefits reflecting 2021 dollars, and it's structured to where students can't access all of it. Also, it wasn't until this month that the hospital recognized certification in specialty areas with monetary compensation. Nurses now receive $1.50/hour extra for certification. Competing hospitals in the area have offered $2/hr for a long time. In summary, for a Magnet designated hospital, educational and certification benefits could be a little more robust in my opinion.

pros:
Med surg ratios 1:5 day shift, 1:6 night shift. Cardiac stepdown 1:4. Hospital is great with staffing and you will never have more than those ratios. People are very nice and friendly.

-Has tons of resources - Resource RN staffed by float pool, IV team that rounds on PICC lines daily- both resource and IV team can assist with IV insertion if need be. IV nurse also available on night shift. Lab always available for draws (except PICC lines) and CNAs on medical short stay obtain their lab draws. They have a good amount of sitters for patients if need be, more than other hospitals I have worked at. Many floors now have mobility techs who are used to walk patients during the day, they are also great with assisting for transfers and moving patients.

No hospital is perfect but this is a pretty great one.
cons:
Pay for RN with 3 years experience $28/hr but I think that is pretty standard for FL

Sarasota is an elderly place, so expect dementia/confused patients 

SMH is downtown so fairly high ETOH/CIWA/homeless patients

pros: great hospital great pay rates/benefits and in general good company to work for just not the department for pre reg scheduling  because of the management
cons: Pre reg department manager for scheduling is horrible, they do not care about the employees in this department, they only care about how fast and how many calls you can take without making any errors so that the upper higher ups look good while we do all the work and get yelled at or disciplined if we do not take as many calls and schedule the appointments they want. They macro manage.  High turn over rates because employees aren’t happy about getting picked at and every single mistake you make pointed out. They watch and monitor your every move like you are in prison, they are not team players at all, management does not help or assist to reach the goals they want us to achieve all they do is bark out do this and do that or you’ll get wrote up. They are not the type of managers to step in and actually help us.

pros: This is a very good hospital.  I have talked to travelers who say that they have worked at better places, however, when I was a student I worked at two other hospitals in the area and neither of them were as good at SMH.  I have been there for 2.5 years and I have met great people, had great training, and worked with great doctors.   They have great internship programs for new grads, they pay for your education, and the other benefits are pretty good as well.   They are well staffed so the patient/nurse ratios are always better than the other hospitals in the area.
cons: The pay is not bad but it is definitely not as high as some other hospitals in the area.   Part of that is because they stay so well staffed and have so little turnover compared to the other hospitals in the area.

pros:
Friendly staff, decent education benefits, patients and visitors are typically well mannered, beautiful city. They do try to make it so that the nurse can remain at bedside, this works best on day shift.
Work pace is usually pretty laid back. Basically this is an OK job if you are planning a working vacation.
cons:
The EMR is a nightmare! Very disjointed, plan on becoming familiar with the employees in IT because you will get booted off the server again and again.
Not as much autonomy as would be expected in an ICU.
Far too much unnecessary patient movement. Expect to admit then transfer same patient to another ICU/floor or even another facility just to admit the patient that should have come to you in the first place.
The computer charting program is bad enough to be mentioned twice.

pros:
They give you all the help you need to get to know the job. 
They have great benefits.
They have great wages.
There seems to be support from management.
They help pay for school.
cons:
There is a lot of favoritism.
You don't want to get on anyone's bad side, because they will hang you out to dry.
There needs to be more teamwork between the nurses and PCTS.
You can't transfer until 6-12 months of working on a unit.
You have to be buddies, with the one that makes the assignment, or you will get the toughest patients.

pros: Amazing team members, ample and educated staff, leadership really cares and great pay
cons: Some leaders in the organization just need to go and make way for more dynamic thinkers and leaders. Presently with the new Venice hospital coming online we seem to be secretly hiring with HCA people which should set us up to manage like one of the worst performing healthcare companies in Florida unlike our amazing flagship main campus. I see the wave coming. Sad

I am in school for radiology and that doesn't benefit the department that I currently work in so I don't qualify for tuition reimbursement; now if I was already working in the Radiology Dept. then I would qualify.
